definition:
Let $X, Y$ be topological spaces. Then a $f : X \rightarrow Y$ is said
to be *sequentially continuous* if for every convergent sequence
$x_n \rightarrow x$ in $X$, $f(x_n) \rightarrow f(x)$ in $Y$.

Every continuous function is sequentially continuous, however the
converse is true only in first-countable spaces (for example in metric
spaces).
